Expectation1: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation1: A customer urgently needs their delivery by the promised time window, such as groceries for dinner
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: A ballot measure affecting their block closes in two hours at the nearby polling place.
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock as I pulled up to the next address, my van loaded with packages and my phone buzzing with reminders. One delivery, a bag of groceries, was marked “urgent”—the customer had called twice, desperate to have everything before dinner. I could picture them waiting, maybe with kids, counting on me to be on time. But as I scanned the list, my eyes caught the sticky note I’d left for myself: “Vote today—polls close at 7.” The polling place was just a few blocks away, and the ballot measure could change parking rules on my street. I’d promised myself I’d participate, be a good citizen, not just complain after the fact. But if I stopped now, I’d risk missing the delivery window and letting down someone who was counting on me. My heart pounded as I weighed the responsibility to my customer against my duty to my community, feeling the pressure of both roles squeezing me from either side.
